labels.name: duplicate
labels.description: This issue or pull request already exists

labels.name: wontfix
labels.description: This will not be worked on

labels.name: ref-impl
labels.description: Issues related to the reference implementation, not the spec

issues.title: Choosing between PQ or PQ/T
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
> guidance on when to use ML-KEM directly versus using it within HPKE would be helpful for protocols that are currently using HPKE

I don't know if we'd resolved on whether there would be a Recommended column in the registry, which is one potentially way of resolving this concern.  Absent that, some discussion of the considerations might be worthwhile.

comments.author: bifurcation
comments.body:
@martinthomson - FWIW, I would note that the text you have quoted does not say "PQ vs PQ/T", it says "ML-KEM vs. HPKE", which is honestly kind of nonsensical because they do different things.

I don't think it's the business of this group to opine on when to use PQ vs. PQ/T.  There is not a "Recommended" column in the registries right now, and I don't think there should be.  (Slim if any evidence for efficacy in guiding good choices.)  In any case, that would be an issue for -hpke, not this doc.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: Discussed 2025-06-06: Sense of the room was to avoid the controversy.  Will confirm on-list.

comments.author: bifurcation
comments.body: Guidance from Deb is that we should have a small comment in the Security Considerations with a high-level note about the differences between pure and hybrid.

comments.author: schanzen
comments.body: I can put my comment from the chat then on the record here as well: I think that the best course of action in order to stay out of the controversy is to only include PQ/T for now. There is really no significant downside to the PQ/T apart from a minor performance hit (and by minor I think negligible tbh). But the PQ-only has security risk attached to it. Putting it into the draft as an "equal" option is putting Internet users at risk atm, because implementors will implement it and provide it. (Understanding the nuanced discussions around PQ-only and PQ/T is difficult to convey even withing the crypto community so I think the task of providing meaningful "guidance" is borderline futile). See also my comment https://github.com/hpkewg/hpke/issues/17 which IMO would be another option where no choice needs to be made and both put in. Then, by having suitable categories such as a recommended column, notice how in the hypothetical year 2035 when ML-KEM is broken and no QC is here it will look a lot less bad if the recommended colum sais "discouraged" or something.

comments.author: bifurcation
comments.body: Addressed in #8

issues.title: Finalize PQ/T hybrids
issues.author: bifurcation
issues.body: The general framework for referencing PQ/T hybrid KEMs was set up in #5.  Those documents are still stabilizing, so we will need to update this document as they firm up.

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body: Should we use XWing or KitchenSink or QSF for ML-KEM768 + X25519?

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body:
The draft presently says QSF (which means XWing).  That matches the feedback that we received on the list.

My understanding is that the reason this issue remains open is to serve as a reminder that any updates to the CFRG drafts need to be properly caught and reflected in the draft.

comments.author: bifurcation
bifurcation
comments.body: As of #35, this is up to date with the current CFRG spec.

issues.title: Add test vectors for some combinations
issues.author: bifurcation
issues.body:
RFC 9180 has test vectors for a few combinations of KDF/KEM/AEAD.  It might be nice for this document to include test vectors for combinations including the KEMs and KDFs defined here, at least the combos that are [likely to be adopted by MLS](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-mahy-mls-pq-00.html):

* Hybrid(X25519 + ML-KEM-768) + SHAKE128 + AES-128-GCM
* Hybrid(P256 + ML-KEM-768) + SHAKE128 + AES-128-GCM
* Hybrid(P384 + ML-KEM-1024) + SHAKE256 + AES-256-GCM
* ML-KEM-768 + SHAKE128 + AES-128-GCM
* ML-KEM-1024 + SHAKE256 + AES-256-GCM

(This is presuming that MLS will use the SHA3 version, as opposed to the SHA2 things that are in the draft now.  TBD)

issues.title: Ref-impl some KDF IDs seem incorrect
issues.author: ilaril
issues.body:
The reference implementation seems to have some KDF identifiers set incorrectly:

* SHAKE256 seems to have ID 0x10, should presumably be 0x11.
  - Line 225 of reference-implementation/src/kdf.rs
* TurboSHAKE128 seems to have ID 0x10, should presumably be 0x12.
  - Line 242 of reference-implementation/src/kdf.rs
* TurboSHAKE256 seems to have ID 0x10, should presumably be 0x13.
  - Line 261 of reference-implementation/src/kdf.rs

(Took me a while to find this while trying to debug why the KDF part of test vectors do not verify against my own HPKE implementation.)

comments.author: bifurcation
comments.body: Good catch @ilaril.  Posted a fix in #28.  Maybe you could verify that the updated test vectors work with your implementation?

issues.title: Should the KDFs include XOF() in them?
issues.author: rohanmahy
issues.body: For example, should the KDF for SHAKE256 be called XOF(SHAKE256) or is SHAKE256 sufficiently unambiguous?

comments.author: bifurcation
comments.body:
The QSF algorithm names are taken from [draft-irtf-cfrg-concrete-hybrid-kems](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-irtf-cfrg-concrete-hybrid-kems/).  This issue should be [over there](https://github.com/cfrg/draft-irtf-cfrg-concrete-hybrid-kems/issues).

Previewing what I'll say there, though:
* The issue title doesn't make sense.  XOFs aren't being used KDFs here, but instead for seed expansion.
* XOF(SHAKE256) is redundant.  SHAKE is an XOF.
* Not sure what your point is about SHA-256.  There is no SHA-2 in this document.

comments.author: bifurcation
comments.body:
Reopening because I misread the issue.

But like I said, XOF(SHAKE256) is redundant. SHAKE is an XOF.

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body:
> The QSF algorithm names are taken from [draft-irtf-cfrg-concrete-hybrid-kems](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-irtf-cfrg-concrete-hybrid-kems/). This issue should be [over there](https://github.com/cfrg/draft-irtf-cfrg-concrete-hybrid-kems/issues).
> 
> Previewing what I'll say there, though:
> 
>     * The issue title doesn't make sense.  XOFs aren't being used KDFs here, but instead for seed expansion.
> 
>     * XOF(SHAKE256) is redundant.  SHAKE is an XOF.

RawSHAKE128 in Section 6.3 of https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/FIPS/NIST.FIPS.202.pdf??

> 
>     * Not sure what your point is about SHA-256.  There is no SHA-2 in this document.

comments.author: bifurcation
comments.body:
> > * XOF(SHAKE256) is redundant.  SHAKE is an XOF.
> 
> RawSHAKE128 in Section 6.3 of https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/FIPS/NIST.FIPS.202.pdf??

Not sure what your point is.  RawSHAKE128 is an intermediate function, not what we're relying on.

And to reiterate, this is an issue for the concrete KEM combiners draft.

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body:
> > > * XOF(SHAKE256) is redundant.  SHAKE is an XOF.
> > 
> > 
> > RawSHAKE128 in Section 6.3 of https://nvlpubs.nist.gov/nistpubs/FIPS/NIST.FIPS.202.pdf??
> 
> Not sure what your point is. RawSHAKE128 is an intermediate function, not what we're relying on.
> 
> And to reiterate, this is an issue for the concrete KEM combiners draft.

NO, this has nothing to do with KEMs! It is the HPKE registered KDFs which are used outside of KEMs.

comments.author: bifurcation
comments.body: Oh, I see.  Well, in that case, XOF is still not relevant.  So you're saying that the names in the [KDF table](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-hpke-pq-01.html#table-1) should have XOF?  That still seems redundant to me.  HPKE doesn't have a notion of XOF, only single-stage KDF.  That's already indicated in the "Two-Stage" column.

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body:
> Oh, I see. Well, in that case, XOF is still not relevant. So you're saying that the names in the [KDF table](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-hpke-pq-01.html#table-1) should have XOF? That still seems redundant to me. HPKE doesn't have a notion of XOF, only single-stage KDF. That's already indicated in the "Two-Stage" column.

I'm saying that whatever is in the KDF table should be clear as to which algorithm is being used. Since I saw the XOF(SHAKE256) terminology in use in other places, I wasn't sure if it was necessary or not.

issues.title: Add hybrid KEM: X448 + ML-KEM-1024
issues.author: jiep
issues.body:
Hi!

Compared to the current proposal of P-384 + ML-KEM-1024, X448 provides stronger security margins for elliptic curve cryptography, better resistance to side-channel attacks, and improved performance in certain implementations, making it a more robust choice for post-quantum hybrid encryption. 

Furthermore, it accelerates the migration to post-quantum cryptography by introducing a secure and streamlined path for current DHKEM(X448, HKDF-SHA512) implementations.

Regards.

comments.author: bifurcation
comments.body: Hi @jiep - Could you please raise this on the [hpke working group mailing list](https://datatracker.ietf.org/group/hpke/email/)?  My impression so far has been that there is not demand for an X448 combination.

comments.author: bifurcation
comments.body: It looks like this was never raised on the mailing list.  It also never showed up on the CFRG list.  Closing for lack of interest.  Code points can always be registered later.

issues.title: Missing dependency `concrete-hybrid-kem`
issues.author: jiep
issues.body:
Steps to reproduce:

1. Clone this repository.
2. Run `cargo build`. The output shows that `concrete-hybrid-kem` has not been found:

```
error: failed to get `concrete-hybrid-kem` as a dependency of package `hpke-ref v0.1.0 (/workspaces/hpke-pq/reference-implementation)`

Caused by:
  failed to load source for dependency `concrete-hybrid-kem`

Caused by:
  Unable to update /workspaces/draft-irtf-cfrg-concrete-hybrid-kems/reference-implementation

Caused by:
  failed to read `/workspaces/draft-irtf-cfrg-concrete-hybrid-kems/reference-implementation/Cargo.toml`

Caused by:
  No such file or directory (os error 2)
```

Where can I find the dependency `concrete-hybrid-kem`?

Thanks in advance. 

Best regards.

comments.author: bifurcation
comments.body:
Hi @jiep -- The `concrete-hybrid-kems` crate is here: https://github.com/cfrg/draft-irtf-cfrg-concrete-hybrid-kems/pull/8.  You'll need to clone that repo/branch yourself and adjust the `path` field in Cargo.toml.

If you have time to file a PR improving the documentation, that would be helpful!

issues.title: Use deterministic encapsulation for the test vectors
issues.author: bifurcation
issues.body:
The CFRG concrete KEMs draft defines an optional [EncapsDerand](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-irtf-cfrg-hybrid-kems-04.html#appendix-A) algorithm that performs deterministic encapsulation.  This is implemented by the hybrid KEMs defined there, and thus by the concrete hybrid KEMs used by this document.

Using EncapsDerand for the test vectors could help implementations verify that their `Setup<Mode>S` implementations are correct as well as their `Setup<Mode>R` implementations.  It would be consistent with the inclusion of `skE` / `pkE` values in the RFC 9180 test vectors.

issues.title: Inflexibility of ikm length and Nsk
issues.author: martinthomson
issues.body:
§3. Existing KEMs only require that len(ikm) ≥ Nsk. In this draft it's
required that len(ikm) = Nsk = 64. This might catch users off guard. For
one, MLS as it's written now will be forced to use HKDF-SHA512 from the
existing set of KDFs. That's a needless lower bound. I see a few options:

1. Accept this breaking change.
2. Always hash down ikm and require len(ikm) ≥ 32.
3. Require len(ikm) ≥ 32 and only hash down ikm to 64 bytes if it's not yet64 bytes.

From @bwesterb [here](https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/hpke/WsFaJbVpkPNaK8Js4TB2ex0BYIw/).

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: I want to point out that truncation is not an option.  `ikm` might have sufficient entropy, but it doesn't have to be compressed (that's what the extract call does).

comments.author: bwesterb
comments.body: For the pure ML-KEM variants, the `ikm` isn't processed any further and as written needs to be 64 bytes, as that is what ML-KEM expects as a seed (even though it only needs 32 bytes of actual entropy in there).

comments.author: FiloSottile
comments.body: Relatedly, the last remaining divergence between draft-connolly-cfrg-xwing-kem and QSF in draft-ietf-hpke-pq is that the former defines HPKE's DeriveKeyPair as `GenerateKeyPairDerand(SHAKE256(ikm, 32*8))`, and the latter defines it (via draft-irtf-cfrg-hybrid-kems's DeriveKeyPair) as `expandDecapsulationKey(seed)` with no additional SHAKE256 step.

comments.author: bifurcation
comments.body:
Having reflected on this a bit, I think the rigidity is probably the right answer at this level:

1. Update draft-ietf-hpke-hpke to specify a separate Nseed for each KEM, and require that the input to DeriveKeyPair MUST have size Nseed
2. For ML-KEM: Make `Nseed = 32` and define a DeriveKeyPair that expands the key (using SHAKE256 or SHA3_512)
3. For the hybrids: Make `Nseed = 32`, as in -concrete-hybrid-kems

That would still leave the awkwardness of, say, an MLS ciphersuite using HKDF-SHA-384 for the key schedule and wanting to use these algorithms.  But I think that layer -- the layer where you connect two algorithms together -- is the right place to decide how to map inputs to outputs.  In this MLS case, for example, the MLS ciphersuite can simply specify that HKDF should produce a shorter output.

Procedurally, I expect (1) is the biggest challenge.  As our charter says, "The Standards Track and Informational versions must have identical behavior for any functionality that they both specify".  However, I think increasing strictness is compatible with that objective.  An implementation built to the older, looser spec will continue to work with any calling code that expects the limitations of the new API.  @martinthomson, thoughts as chair?

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body:
We'd probably want to float that with a wider audience, but it seems like - as long as there is no need for more input entropy and as long as old implementations that accept more are acknowledged as being mostly OK - that seems like it is within the spirit of the charter.

Did you mean 32 or 64 for ML-KEM?  [32 bytes of entropy, 64 bytes in size](https://github.com/hpkewg/hpke-pq/issues/30#issuecomment-3166909668)...

comments.author: bwesterb
comments.body:
> That would still leave the awkwardness of, say, an MLS ciphersuite using HKDF-SHA-384 for the key schedule and wanting to use these algorithms

I don't see why this is the case.

> Update draft-ietf-hpke-hpke to specify a separate Nseed for each KEM, and require that the input to DeriveKeyPair MUST have size Nseed

What is the reasoning to disallow longer inputs? I don't see harm if we're going to plop it into SHAKE256 anyway.

comments.author: bifurcation
comments.body: Mailing list discussion: https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/hpke/Sq2apDTygF4F6-ZLevVGukKxsJE/

issues.title: New DHKEM identifiers?
issues.author: bifurcation
issues.body:
In trying to be more systematic with test vectors, I added a DHKEM KEM with EC groups and SHAKE.  Since this is a legal combination, and something new introduced here, it seemed good to test it.  Should we register KEM identifiers for these?  And if not, should we use more "vendor space" looking identifiers?  Here's what is in the reference implementation now:

| ID     | Algorithm               |
|--------|-------------------------|
| 0x0017 | DHKEM(P-256, SHAKE128)  |
| 0x0018 | DHKEM(P-384, Shake256)  |
| 0x0019 | DHKEM(P-521, Shake256)  |
| 0x0023 | DHKEM(X25519, SHAKE128) |
| 0x0024 | DHKEM(X448, Shake256)   |

comments.author: FiloSottile
comments.body:
A legal and already testable combination is e.g. DHKEM(P-256, HKDF-SHA256) as KEM and SHAKE128 as KDF. That works and doesn't require any new codepoints.

The question is whether to define _new_ KEM codepoints that use DHKEM with one-step KDFs. IMHO, it's not worth it. It's much nicer to have one KEM per curve, and the SHAKE KDFs were mostly introduced to go along with the PQ KEMs. It's telling that no one ever asked for these.

In any case, we can always add them later, even just with a trivial IANA request, so I would not hold up the documents to discuss them.

comments.author: bifurcation
comments.body:
My only concern with that approach is that we end up with un-tested functionality.  Specifically, we wouldn't have any testing on the [`DeriveCandidate_OneStage`](https://github.com/hpkewg/hpke/blob/main/draft-ietf-hpke-hpke.md#derivekeypair-derive-key-pair) method.  To test that, you need a KEM ID (via `LabeledDerive`).

Now, maybe I'm over-thinking this.  `LabeledDerive` is used elsewhere, so if you don't have a working implementation of that, you'll fail other test vectors with SHAKE in the KDF position.  The only things you could possibly screw up in `DeriveCandidate_OneStage` are the inputs: `ikm`, the label `"candidate"`, the encoded counter, and the length `Nsk`.

And maybe another way to think of this is to punt: If/when someone wants to register a DHKEM variant that uses a one-stage KDF, they'll get a code point and they can publish test vectors.

Given the above, I would be OK closing this.  I'll leave it open another 24 hours or so in case anyone else has thoughts.  I might add a note to the test vector description saying we don't cover this case.

comments.author: FiloSottile
comments.body:
> And maybe another way to think of this is to punt: If/when someone wants to register a DHKEM variant that uses a one-stage KDF, they'll get a code point and they can publish test vectors.

Yeah that's how I think about it. The part that's untested is the part that's unspecified, which sounds right.

> I might add a note to the test vector description saying we don't cover this case.

Maybe add a note to the `DeriveCandidate_OneStage` definition saying that no currently defined KEMs use a one-stage KDF?

I actually think I will de-implement it from my implementation, until such a time we have a need for it.

issues.title: Conversion from private key to public key is unclear
issues.author: FiloSottile
issues.body:
I can't decide if this is an issue with hpke-pq or with RFC 9180, but there doesn't seem to be a function I can reference to turn a seed / private key / decapsulation key into its public key / encapsulation key.

DeserializePrivateKey/SerializePrivateKey and DeserializePublicKey/SerializePublicKey are the identity, because Encaps/Decaps take byte slices themselves. I am actually a big fan of this specification approach. But a side-effect is that there is no implicit relationship between the private key byte slice and the public key byte slice.

It's not hard to figure out, or even ambiguous: it can be inferred from keygen, and obviously the answer is 

```
def PrivateKeyToPublicKey(seed):
    ek_PQ, ek_T, _, _ = expandKey(seed)
    ek = ek_PQ || ek_T

    return ek
```

Still, I was trying to describe how to turn a private key into a public key and I can't find a way to refer to it.

One interpretation is that RFC 9180 intended for DeserializePrivateKey to turn the sk into a KEM-internal representation, for which the KEM would then define a private-to-public operation, and the SerializePublicKey operates on the result. Another interpretation is that this is an oversight in RFC 9180 and should be fixed in hpke-hpke. Or maybe it's (also) an issue in the CFRG documents, and then whatever is added to those should be referenced from hpke-pq?

issues.title: Markdown missing "IkmE" field
issues.author: clundin25
issues.body: It's in the JSON file but `json-to-markdown.rs` seems to omit it.

issues.title: Missing SHAKE in ML-KEM DeriveKeyPair
issues.author: clundin25
issues.body:
The reference implementation applies a SHAKE operation to `ikm` in the ML-KEM DeriveKeyPair function of the reference implementation [src](https://github.com/hpkewg/hpke-pq/blob/main/reference-implementation/src/kem.rs#L169).

The spec does not mention this operation in the specification https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-hpke-pq-01.html#section-3.

Can you clarify this inconsistency?

comments.author: panva
comments.body: @clundin25 https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-hpke-pq-03.html#section-3

comments.author: clundin25
comments.body: Thank you @panva. That clears this up!

pulls.title: Add support for single-stage KDFs
pulls.author: bifurcation
pulls.body:
Corresponds to https://github.com/hpkewg/hpke/pull/16

Not sure we need all six of these?

comments.author: bifurcation
comments.body: I guess it makes sense to keep both SHAKE and TurboSHAKE in case FIPS-y people don't like TurboSHAKE?
KT only makes sense for inputs longer than 24kB. Does HPKE ever pass such long inputs to the KDF?

In principle, it's possible via the `info` parameter going into `KeySchedule`.  But it seems quite unlikely, and even then, there's a hard max of 64k, at least according to the current content of https://github.com/hpkewg/hpke/pull/16.  Given that, I would probably drop KT.

pulls.title: Reflect WG adoption
pulls.author: bifurcation
pulls.body: Also fix a minor MD error.

pulls.title: Define HPKE KEMs using PQ/T hybrid KEMs
pulls.author: bifurcation
pulls.body:
CFRG has two drafts in progress for hybrid KEMs:

* [draft-irtf-cfrg-hybrid-kems](https://cfrg.github.io/draft-irtf-cfrg-hybrid-kems/draft-irtf-cfrg-hybrid-kems.html) defines general schemes for constructing PQ/T hybrid KEMs from a T group/KEM and a PQ KEM.
* [draft-irtf-cfrg-concrete-hybrid-kems](https://github.com/cfrg/draft-irtf-cfrg-concrete-hybrid-kems/blob/main/draft-irtf-cfrg-concrete-hybrid-kems.md) defines a few specific instantiations of the general schemes.

(Note that I am referring to the GitHub / editor's copies of these docs for now, since the authors of those docs haven't yet released new drafts reflecting the required changes.  Should be soon.)

This PR just maps the KEM interface from those documents to the HPKE one, and registers KEM IDs for the hybrid KEMs.

Also, as a bit of terminology cleanup, we use "IND-CCA2" to talk about public-key encryption, and "IND-CCA" to talk about KEMs, since this seems to be the standard terminology.

comments.author: bifurcation
comments.body: Also: KEM names are likely to change as the bikeshed gets painted, so regard these names as pretty provisional.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: Action to take a question about the use of SHA-2 in these KEMs.  Just to confirm that there isn't anyone who is stuck on CNSA 2.0 and so needs a combination with those.

Would this be better?

```suggestion
HNN3:
: P-256 + ML-KEM-768

HNN5:
: P-384 + ML-KEM-1024

HNX:
: X25519 + ML-KEM-768
{: spacing="compact"}
```
With or without `()` on each of these?  `GenerateKeyPair()` sticks out.

pulls.title: typo fix
pulls.author: loganaden

pulls.title: Mention ML-KEM-512 in the intro
pulls.author: dconnolly

pulls.title: Add security considerations about PQ/T hybrid vs. pure PQ
pulls.author: bifurcation
pulls.body:
As discussed in #17 and at the 2025-06-06 interim, this PR makes a couple of caveats:

* ML-KEM-512 is noted to be "not suitable for general use on the Internet"
* The security considerations get a note describing the difference between hybrid and pure PQ

comments.body:
```suggestion
security properties.
```

```suggestion
{:aside}
> Note: While this document defines an HPKE KEM for ML-KEM-512 in the interest
```

Not taking any position on Quynh's feedback on the list.

It's a bit more subtle than that. At the time of writing there is no peer-reviewed evidence that ML-KEM-512 doesn't reach its claimed security level (AES-128). ML-KEM-768 is a hedge against cryptanalytic improvement.

```suggestion
> is not catastrophic, at a modest performance penalty.
```

```suggestion
quantum attacker.  In environments where there is concern that (an implementation of) ML-KEM might not
```

I think it's more fair to ML-KEM to make it more explicit that we're more worried about implementation concerns than to keep casting doubt about the algorithm itself.

pulls.title: Clean up the pure ML-KEM section
pulls.author: bifurcation
pulls.body:
Inspired by [a PR comment](https://github.com/hpkewg/hpke-pq/pull/5#pullrequestreview-2898620188) from @martinthomson, this PR cleans up the same `()` notation in the pure ML-KEM KEM definitions.

It also removes the mention of AuthEncap / AuthDecap, since these have been removed from draft-ietf-hpke-hpke.

pulls.title: Add a reference implementation and test vectors
pulls.author: bifurcation
pulls.body:
This PR adds a reference implementation that leverages the corresponding reference implementations for [hybrid KEMs](https://github.com/cfrg/draft-irtf-cfrg-hybrid-kems/pull/33) and [concrete hybrid KEMs](https://github.com/cfrg/draft-irtf-cfrg-concrete-hybrid-kems/pull/8), then uses it to add test vectors.

It also updates the names of the hybrid constructions to match the current names in the [concrete hybrid KEMs repo](https://github.com/cfrg/draft-irtf-cfrg-concrete-hybrid-kems/blob/main/draft-irtf-cfrg-concrete-hybrid-kems.md#concrete-hybrid-kem-instances), and assigns values to the KDF registrations.

Fixes #11

pulls.title: Fix some references
pulls.author: martinthomson
pulls.body:
draft-barnes-hpke-hpke is easy.

The \[CONCRETE] reference isn't so obvious.  I think that the intent was to reference the hybrid-kems draft, from context.

comments.author: bifurcation

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body: My bad.  I missed a PQC for engineers reference

This is wrong.  The KEM interface is defined in the generic doc, i.e., draft-irtf-cfrg-hybrid-kems.  Suggest making two references GENERIC and CONCRETE, which can both point to draft-irtf-cfrg-hybrid-kems for now, and then CONCRETE will get moved over once that is published.
If we're going to have a nickname, let's put it above, not inline.
Redefinition of the nickname.
This should be GENERIC.
This should be GENERIC.
Redefinition is fine, but - for you - I'll fix it.

pulls.title: Auth modes of RFC9180 and limitations of KEMs
pulls.author: thomwiggers
pulls.body:
Security considerations seemed to make sense, but this section could also go into the introduction.

I did not get too technical ("DH is a NIKE, KEMs are not NIKE"), but if we want that is an option.

If there's a better way to link to a paragraph in another draft, that'd be a great improvement over my hard-coded section number.

reviews.author: bifurcation
reviews.body:
FWIW, the [text that was removed](https://github.com/hpkewg/hpke-pq/pull/10/files#diff-19fbaf93b7b41ba746f54a68220cf10d39decc31ebad0a21e8acb4b07263013bL185) was smaller and inline with the KEM definition:

> The `AuthEncap()` and `AuthDecap()` functions are not implemented.

But I can see the appeal of having this in the Security Considerations.  If we did the inline approach, we would at least have to repeat it for the hybrid KEMs.

comments.body:
```suggestion
PSK-authenticated HPKE ({{Section 5.1.2 of HPKE}})
or digital signatures may be suitable alternatives.
```

(Note: `{{HPKE}}` will break the build until #20 lands.)

```suggestion
cannot be used to migrate uses of HPKE that rely on this mode.
```
I take it that there's no secret way to use the `#mode-psk` (or whatever it is) anchor?
That doesn't exist, sadly.  I've considering doing that work, but it's not a simple thing to do.  So, obviously, this will rot.
Yeah, I figured as much. I guess that's why our registration fees are funding the RFC editors.

```suggestion
PSK-authenticated HPKE ({{Section 5.1.2 of I-D.barnes-hpke-hpke}})
```

```suggestion
PSK-authenticated HPKE ({{Section 5.1.2 of I-D.ietf-hpke-hpke}})
```

Or are you looking to reference the draft explicitly?
@bifurcation committed this change so I'm not sure why this got changed to the draft version.

pulls.title: Re-use the existing X-Wing code point
pulls.author: bifurcation
pulls.body: https://mailarchive.ietf.org/arch/msg/hpke/r4_lx0mtSy6wZjT62ldxYUzqQcU/

comments.author: dconnolly
comments.body:
> Actually, this is interesting, which one 'wins'? They are interoperable and identical but (this is a purely procedural / IANA question)

I ask because people are using X-Wing as defined in the other document using this codepoint, it shouldn't matter for interop I'm mostly curious, I wonder if that results in confusion

comments.author: davidben
comments.body:
Is it any different from what would happen had draft-connolly-cfrg-xwing-kem-06 been adopted by hpkewg and then eventually morphed into this document, while staying compatible? We'd presumably update the reference to the final RFC in that case.

I guess the name of the construction has changed. Although with ridiculous names like `DHKEM(P-256, HKDF-SHA256)` and `QSF-X25519-MLKEM768-SHAKE256-SHA3256`, I doubt people were using them as-is anyway. (Why do we keep doing this to ourselves?)

comments.author: dconnolly
comments.body:
> Is it any different from what would happen had draft-connolly-cfrg-xwing-kem-06 been adopted by hpkewg and then eventually morphed into this document, while staying compatible? We'd presumably update the reference to the final RFC in that case.
> 
> I guess it's the name of the construction has changed. Although with ridiculous names like `DHKEM(P-256, HKDF-SHA256)` and `QSF-X25519-MLKEM768-SHAKE256-SHA3256`, I doubt people were using them as-is anyway.

Good point, ok

comments.author: davidben
comments.body:
> ridiculous names

2 cents: I know HPKE's convention is to write in every parameter, but I might suggest names like "P256-MLKEM768", "P384-MLKEM1024", and "X25519-MLKEM768" would have been slightly more practical, and more likely to end up with implementations aligning on names. It's okay if some parameters aren't represented. One hopes we're not going to define another version of these. If we do, it can always add a short suffix like "X25519-MLKEM768-v2" or "X25519-MLKEM768-SHA4" or something.

After all, it's ML-KEM-768, not ML-KEM-768-SHAKE256-SHA3256-SHAKE256-SHA3512-SHAKE128. :-)

comments.author: bifurcation
comments.body: @davidben - I agree with you, but @dconnolly pushed for more stuff.  And in any case, that's an issue for https://github.com/cfrg/draft-irtf-cfrg-concrete-hybrid-kems/

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body:
> > ridiculous names
> 
> 2 cents: I know HPKE's convention is to write in every parameter, but I might suggest names like "P256-MLKEM768", "P384-MLKEM1024", and "X25519-MLKEM768" would have been slightly more practical, and more likely to end up with implementations aligning on names. It's okay if some parameters aren't represented. One hopes we're not going to define another version of these. If we do, it can always add a short suffix like "X25519-MLKEM768-v2" or "X25519-MLKEM768-SHA4" or something.
> 
> After all, it's ML-KEM-768, not ML-KEM-768-SHAKE256-SHA3256-SHAKE256-SHA3512-SHAKE128. :-)

I used:

`QSF-KEM(ML-KEM-768,X25519)` for the KEM name inside the MLS ciphersuite names in draft-mahy-mls-pq. The resulting MLS cipher suite names are already quite long. For example:

`MLS_128_QSF-KEM(ML-KEM-768,X25519)_AES256GCM_SHA384_Ed25519`

I realize that parentheses and commas have not been used to date in KEM names, but I couldn't find anything preventing use of these characters. I think the parentheses make it very clear that QSF is combining those two things.

As suggested above, we could use QSF-KEM(ML-KEM-768,X25519)v2 of -2 if we need to change one of the support algorithms inside.

comments.author: richsalz
comments.body:
Commas and parens might be problematic when you start to configure these things as a list. Emphasis on *might*

Perhaps we can look to other IETF specs for short names, like JOSE?

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body:
> Commas and parens might be problematic when you start to configure these things as a list. Emphasis on _might_

To speak specifically for MLS, the ciphersuite in the protocol is identified by an integer. The label is for consistent identification. 

And certainly if someone wants a list of labels, they should be able to put the ciphersuite labels or HPKE labels in quotes. 

> Perhaps we can look to other IETF specs for short names, like JOSE?

The algorithms in JOSE are JSON strings, so as long as they don't have double quotes or backslashes, they should be ok.

comments.author: richsalz
comments.body: Most TLS stacks (derived from OpenSSL), and therefore many applications, use text strings to configure ciphers. That is what I was thinking of. Not the protocol-level.

comments.author: rohanmahy
comments.body: Nobody liked my parentheses, but there was plenty of desire for shorter names, so I proposed shorter KEM names without parens.

reviews.author: dconnolly
reviews.body: Actually, this is interesting, which one 'wins'? They are interoperable and identical but (this is a purely procedural / IANA question)

comments.body:

```suggestion
| 0x0050 | QSF-P256-MLKEM768   | 32       | 1153 | 1249 | 32  | no   | RFCXXXX   |
```

I agree with this change, but I also think that this registry should use the same names that are in the CFRG concrete hybrid KEMs draft.  So I would prefer not to make this change until the change is made upstream.

comments.author: ilaril
comments.body:
Testing against my own implementation (with more extensive set of algorithms), I get the following failures:

* All ML-KEM tests fail due to wrong private key length.
  * If I hack tests to use ikmr as the private key, tests — including private key / public key consistency check — pass.
  * skRm in test vectors does not look sane.
* ~~X-Wing test fails due to wrong private key length.~~
  * ~~Hacking code to use ikmr still gives wrong private key length error — with different length value.~~
  * ~~Both ikmr and skRm in test vectors do not look sane.~~
  * ~~I have not debugged this further to discover exactly where things go wrong.~~
* ~~All (Turbo)Shake256 tests fail with wrong key error.~~
  * ~~(Turbo)Shake128 looks fine.~~
  * ~~exporter_secret in test vectors does not look sane.~~
  * ~~Presumably because these incorrectly set N_H to 32 instead of 64 — I have not tested if this would fix the failures.~~
 
(The two other hybrids can not be tested because I do not have an implementation of those.)

Edit:
* The ML-KEM failures seem to come from cfrg/draft-irtf-cfrg-concrete-hybrid-kems ML-KEM code using dk instead of ikm as the private key  — this would explain why hacking the code to use ikmr worked.
* ~~And the X-Wing failure seems to come from cfrg/draft-irtf-cfrg-hybrid-kems reference-implementation/src/qsf.rs incorrectly setting the seed length — this would explain why hacking the code to use ikmr would still fail — and using dk_hybrid instead of seed as the private key.~~
* Tested that the "Fix Nh for SHAKE256" commit fixes the SHAKE256 failures.
* All the code got merged into cfrg/draft-irtf-cfrg-concrete-hybrid-kems, and X-Wing tests seem to pass now.

comments.author: FiloSottile
comments.body:
At FiloSottile/age#651 I have an implementation of QSF with P-256 and of X-Wing that interoperate with https://github.com/hpkewg/hpke-pq/commit/19adaeb (this PR +
https://github.com/hpkewg/hpke-pq/pull/32 for deterministic Encaps) and https://github.com/cfrg/draft-irtf-cfrg-concrete-hybrid-kems/commit/1bbca40 (https://github.com/cfrg/draft-irtf-cfrg-concrete-hybrid-kems/pull/16, now merged).

I don't have keygen in production code since I need this for hardware keys, but my test code [does reduce the seed against the order of the base field](https://github.com/FiloSottile/age/pull/651/commits/8c3427364d79649f306fb2aecbdc10ee0dc20b5f#diff-ed946ce8a529cfaf734fa0a5ef96e138ec17811572adf7eda1eaa6dfa941b082R208) to pass the test vectors, which I think is the bug @ilaril identified in the draft-irtf-cfrg-concrete-hybrid-kems reference code.

pulls.title: Correct reference to concrete hybrid KEM document
pulls.author: bifurcation
pulls.body: Fixes errors in #20

pulls.title: Include encapsulation randomness in test vectors
pulls.author: FiloSottile
pulls.body:
It wasn't obvious what to use for EncapDerand of DHKEM.

RFC 9180 uses rejection sampling for DeriveKeyPair, but includes a scalar in the test vectors (which is not really an EncapDerand input).

draft-irtf-cfrg-hybrid-kems defines the EncapsDerand of a nominal group to be reduction based.

Since DHKEM already has a DeriveKeyPair, I went for that.

Fixes #29

pulls.title: Fix Nenc and Npk of QSF-P384-MLKEM1024-SHAKE256-SHA3256
pulls.author: FiloSottile
pulls.body:
A P-384 element is 97 bytes (384 / 8 * 2 + 1), plus 1568 bytes of ML-KEM-1024 ciphertext or public key.

Not sure where the previous numbers came from.

comments.author: martinthomson
comments.body:
1600 is 1568 + 32, which would make sense for X25519+ML-KEM-1024.
1120 is the size of X25519+ML-KEM-768.

Are the others correct?  They look good to me.

pulls.title: Reference implementation: use git to fetch dependency
pulls.author: thomwiggers
pulls.body: This allows it to compile on more people's machines

pulls.title: Update names; editorial fixes
pulls.author: bifurcation

pulls.title: Use seed format for private keys and expand seed
pulls.author: bifurcation
pulls.body: Fixes #30

comments.author: dconnolly
comments.body: This change would not be FIPS compatible as I understand it in October 2025; also I don't understand the need for a divergent seed format in the pure MLKEM case (64 bytes vs 32 bytes)
If you care, I do not think this is FIPS compatible
Why are you proposing a 32byte seed for pure MLKEM?

Paging @bwesterb

It seems like if 32 bytes is good enough for the hybrids -- ML-KEM plus something else -- then it ought to be good enough for ML-KEM alone?

But why? Just to copy? This would make ML-KEM decaps keys for HPKE vary from most other ML-KEM implementations that use the 64 byte (d, z) format that is FIPS/spec-compatible. 

I'm pretty sure this is not allowed by FIPS 203 and SP 800-133 (existing and upcoming updates, unless they decide to change their mind and support XOFs like SHAKE to source seeds, as opposed to their explicit KDFs)

reviews.author: FiloSottile
reviews.body: I like using SHAKE256.LabeledDerive, LGTM with the note about removing the minimum ikm length.

comments.body: In RFC 9180 a long enough ikm is a SHOULD, not a MUST, and I don't think doing DeriveKeyPair on 128 bits of entropy would be always unreasonable. IMHO we should no check the length here.

Very weak preference for `"DeriveKeyPair"`. Putting ML-KEM and not ML-KEM-768 in there feels off, and the actual KEM is already separated by suite_id, so leaning on the side of removing ML-KEM instead of adding the parameter size.
I think you are missing `SerializePrivateKey` and `DeserializePrivateKey` descriptions, similarly trivial.

```suggestion
  the function `DeriveKeyPair` from {{GENERIC}} to compute the key pair for the
```
Same as above on removing the minimum ikm length.
Same as above on using `"DeriveKeyPair"` and letting the suite_id do the work.
Same as above on missing SerializePrivateKey and DeserializePrivateKey.

From a security standpoint this is fine.

From a compliance standpoint, I'd like to remark that we've been wrong many times on such details and have many times underestimated the willingness of NIST to allow the reasonable thing.

The primary objection I see is that the established seed private-key format for ML-KEM is 64 bytes—not 32 bytes.

We are not defining a seed format here, especially not a 32-bytes one. The Serialize/DeserializePrivateKey functions are still defined to take the FIPS 203 64-byte seed.

What this PR is doing is defining the DeriveKeyPair interface required by HPKE, which takes arbitrary length inputs. I think calling that input a seed only caused confusion. DeriveKeyPair is not required to use HPKE, so applications with strong FIPS compliance requirements can just do GenerateKeyPair and Serialize/DeserializePrivateKey.

```suggestion
```

9180 says 'For a given KEM, the ikm parameter given to DeriveKeyPair() SHOULD have length at least Nsk, and SHOULD have at least Nsk bytes of entropy.' It does not specify that the input MUST be arbitrary length, especially per-KEM. For the existing definitions including use of HKDF inside DH-KEM, there are in fact maximum allowed lengths for IKM, and the RECOMMENDED limits are exactly 64 bytes: So it seems we have implicit mins and maxes for IKM anyway. I do agree with Bas that this is not insecure, it just seems to be an extra complication.

That section explicitly calls them variable-length parameters. It's not a MUST, but it looks pretty explicit to me.

Fundamentally, I think an application that passes 16, 48, or 64 bytes to DeriveKeyPair is using RFC 9180 correctly, and a new KEM can't break the abstraction by rejecting them. The whole point of HPKE is to be an abstraction.
I do like the included label here

pulls.author: bifurcation

pulls.title: Update reference implementation
pulls.author: bifurcation
pulls.body: ... to match the latest changes in the hybrid KEMs reference implementation.

comments.author: bifurcation
comments.body: Thanks for the feedback @martinthomson.  I'm going to update #36 with the semantic changes, so I'll add the assertions there.
Shouldn't this assert that randomness is >= N_SEED (or ==)

Given these constants, there's a scary option:


```suggestion
    fn deserialize_public_key(pkXm: &[u8; Self::N_PK]) -> Self::EncapsulationKey {
```

You'd have to redefine the trait to include the constants, of course.

That doesn't work with this using the Ciphertext alias from the ML-KEM crate though.
Yeah, until we get nicer const generics, I'll settle for an `assert!()`.

To be perfectly blunt, const generics are good enough for what you are seeking to do here.  They have been for a while.  You can't do sums or conditions, but for what you have, with constants for everything, you don't need that.  You could avoid the need for bounds-checking, if nothing else.

pulls.title: Edits to comply with RFC style guide
pulls.author: bifurcation

pulls.title: Add Deirdre Connolly as an author
pulls.author: bifurcation
pulls.body: Deirdre's work on [ML-KE](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-connolly-cfrg-hpke-mlkem/04/), [SHA-3](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-connolly-cfrg-sha3-hpke/) and [X-Wing](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-connolly-cfrg-xwing-kem-09.html#name-use-in-hpke) in HPKE predated this draft and originated a lot of ideas that are in this draft.

pulls.title: Improve testing of the reference implementation
pulls.author: bifurcation
pulls.body:
Turns out we weren't actually testing that the test vectors passed on the round-trip tests, and some things were broken.  (Thanks, AI!)  Also, something about the RC builds of the elliptic curve library is currently broken, so I reverted to the stable one.

Together with recent changes to `concrete-hybrid-kems`, this should render the test vectors more sane.  As a first check, since Circl seemed to have HPKE and X-Wing implementations that could be plugged together, I added a small script that uses Circl to verify the test vectors.  Since the binary format is fixed now, as we get more implementations of the hybrid KEMs, it could be good to add more similar verifiers / CI.

* Actually run the Circl verifier on the PQ test vectors in CI
* Be more systematic about the set of test vectors generated
* Remove remaining references to QSF
* Regenerate test vectors

This work raised a new issue: https://github.com/hpkewg/hpke-pq/issues/43
